article: The turning point of my life was my decision to give up a promising business career and study music. My parents, although sharing my love of music, didn't  _  it as a profession. My grandfather, having taught music for years at college and, though much  _  , earned merely enough to support his family. As a result of this  _  in the family, I went to college -----quite  _  , for although I loved my violin and spent most of my spare time practicing, I had many other  _  . Before my graduation from Columbia, I felt  _  my duty to leave college and take a job. Aside from the satisfaction of being able to  _  the family, money is all I got out of it. My only ambition was to save enough to  give up  the job and go to Europe to study  _  . I used to get up at dawn to practice  before  I left for "downtown "to work. . I continued to make money, and  _  , bit by bit, accumulated enough to enable me to  go abroad  . The situation of my family improved, and my help was  no longer  necessary, so I resigned from my  _  and, feeling like a man released from jail, sailed for  Europe  . I stayed four years, worked harder than I had ever dreamed of working before and  _  every minute of it. I was a  _  man and I was doing what I  _  to do and what I was meant to do. If I had stayed in business, I might be a quite wealthy man today,  _  I wouldn't have made a success of living . I would have  _  all those that money can never buy. Money is a wonderful thing, but it is possible to pay too high price on it.
